newsitem.title: ITALY: Italians bid tearful farewell to Mastroianni.
newsitem.headline: Italians bid tearful farewell to Mastroianni.

text.p: Marcello Mastroianni returned home on Saturday as thousands of Romans paid their last respects to the actor who immortalised their city's exuberance in "La Dolce Vita".
Friends and fans streamed to Rome's Capitoline city hall to bid farewell to Mastroianni, who died of cancer in Paris on Thursday at the age of 72.
His body was flown back to Rome earlier on Saturday and will lie in state in the Michelangelo-designed palace until a civil funeral on Sunday at his family tomb in Rome.

"Mastroianni was a great interpreter of Italian art and as an ambassador of this art in the world, he showed exemplary humanity," said President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro, who was one of the first to file past the simple wooden coffin.
"He was a prince," added French actress Catherine Deneuve, with whom Mastroianni had a love affair and a daughter, Chiara.

Deneuve, Chiara, Mastroianni's wife Flora -- whom he never divorced -- their daughter Barbara and Anna-Maria Tato, his companion of the last 22 years, sat watching as the public poured into the city hall.
Mastroianni starred in some 160 films opposite many of cinema's most beautiful women but he always rejected the "Latin lover" label.
He will be remembered above all as a warm, humble man.
"He was magnificent professional and an honest man with a heart of gold," opera superstar Luciano Pavarotti was quoted as telling AGI news agency from Prague.
Mastroianni made 12 movies with Italian diva Sophia Loren but was best known for his role in Federico Fellini's 1960 "La Dolce Vita" (The Sweet Life).
Mastroianni starred in other films by Fellini, who died in 1993, but it was "La Dolce Vita" that secured him stardom as a reporter who chronicles the decadant life of contemporary Rome.

"The sweet life for a long time meant a crazy, frivolous life," said Rome mayor Francesco Rutelli. "But Mastroianni brought home the literal meaning of the term. He was a man of great irony, moderation and joy de vivre."
Prime Minister Romano Prodi paid tribute to the actor at city hall, as did directors Michelangelo Antonioni, Marco Risi and Citto Maselli and musician Manuel De Sica.
Mastroianni had been active until the very end, starring in Milan in a play called "Le Ultime Lune" (The Last Moons), a work by Italian dramatist Furio Bordon that talks about old age.
"Six days ago he told me he was sorry he had to interrupt the play but that we would start working again soon," Giulio Bosetti, the play's director, told reporters.
"He knew what was happening but wanted to show he didn't believe it, that he still wanted to do theatre," he added.
